tasks.audioText: The employee has been with the company for fifteen years but feels undervalued. It's high time the management recognized his contributions to the department.
tasks.transcript: It's high time the management recognized his contributions to the department.

options.text: The management already acknowledged his work long ago.
Recognition of his efforts by the leadership is long overdue.
He has no significant contributions to recognize.
The management plans to fire him soon.

tasks.explanation: 'It's high time + past tense' expresses that something should have happened already but hasn't. Recognition is overdue.

tasks.audioText: The couple argued about their holiday plans. She said she would rather they spent the summer in the countryside than at a crowded resort.
tasks.transcript: She said she would rather they spent the summer in the countryside than at a crowded resort.

options.text: She preferred a rural summer holiday over a busy resort destination.
She wanted to go to a crowded resort.
They already spent the summer in the countryside.
She does not want to go on holiday at all.

tasks.explanation: 'Would rather + past tense' expresses a preference for an unreal or hypothetical situation. She prefers the countryside over a resort.

tasks.audioText: The mentor spoke candidly with the young entrepreneur. Suppose you lost all your funding tomorrow — would your business model still be viable?
tasks.transcript: Suppose you lost all your funding tomorrow — would your business model still be viable?

options.text: The entrepreneur has actually lost all funding.
The mentor asks hypothetically whether the business could survive without any financial backing.
The business model is guaranteed to succeed regardless.
The mentor is offering additional funding.

tasks.explanation: 'Suppose + past tense' creates a hypothetical scenario about the present or future. The mentor tests the business model's resilience through an imagined situation.

tasks.audioText: The therapist worked with a patient struggling with perfectionism. I'd rather you didn't put so much pressure on yourself to be flawless in every situation.
tasks.transcript: I'd rather you didn't put so much pressure on yourself to be flawless in every situation.

options.text: The therapist encourages the patient to strive for perfection.
The therapist would prefer that the patient stop demanding perfection from themselves all the time.
The patient has already overcome perfectionism.
The therapist is indifferent to the patient's struggles.

tasks.explanation: 'I'd rather you didn't' uses the unreal past to express a polite preference about another person's behaviour. The therapist gently advises reducing self-imposed pressure.

tasks.audioText: The politician faced criticism for delaying reforms. It's about time the government addressed the growing inequality in the education system.
tasks.transcript: It's about time the government addressed the growing inequality in the education system.

options.text: The government has already successfully tackled educational inequality.
There is no inequality in the education system.
Action on the widening educational gap should have been taken much sooner.
The government does not consider education a priority.

tasks.explanation: 'It's about time + past tense' implies that action is overdue. The speaker criticizes the delay in addressing educational inequality.

tasks.audioText: The manager discussed team dynamics with a senior colleague. I wish my team communicated more openly, rather than letting issues fester until they become serious problems.
tasks.transcript: I wish my team communicated more openly, rather than letting issues fester until they become serious problems.

options.text: The manager's team already communicates very openly.
The manager desires better communication from the team instead of problems being left unaddressed.
The manager does not care about team communication.
The team has no communication problems.

tasks.explanation: 'I wish + past tense' expresses an unreal present desire. The team currently does not communicate well, and the manager wants this to change.

tasks.audioText: The professor discussed ethical dilemmas in the philosophy seminar. Imagine you had to choose between saving one person you love and five strangers — what would you do?
tasks.transcript: Imagine you had to choose between saving one person you love and five strangers — what would you do?

options.text: The professor describes a real emergency that is happening right now.
The students have already faced this exact dilemma in real life.
The professor poses a hypothetical moral choice between a loved one and five unknown people.
The professor thinks this situation is impossible to imagine.

tasks.explanation: 'Imagine + past tense' creates a hypothetical scenario using the unreal past. It is a thought experiment, not a real situation.

tasks.audioText: The diplomat reflected on the failed negotiations. If only both parties had shown greater willingness to compromise, the ceasefire might have held.
tasks.transcript: If only both parties had shown greater willingness to compromise, the ceasefire might have held.

options.text: Both sides were extremely willing to compromise.
The ceasefire is still in effect today.
Had both sides been more open to concessions, the truce could have survived.
The negotiations were a complete success.

tasks.explanation: 'If only + past perfect' expresses regret about a past situation. The ceasefire failed because neither side compromised enough.

tasks.audioText: The patient sat anxiously in the waiting room. He acted as if he already knew the diagnosis, though the results hadn't been released yet.
tasks.transcript: He acted as if he already knew the diagnosis, though the results hadn't been released yet.

options.text: He had already received his diagnosis.
He behaved as though he were aware of the outcome, even though the findings were still unreleased.
He was completely calm and unconcerned.
The results had been released earlier that day.

tasks.explanation: 'As if + past tense' describes behaviour that does not match reality. He appeared to know the diagnosis, but the results were not out yet.

tasks.audioText: The housing crisis deepened across the country. It's time the authorities took decisive action to increase affordable housing construction.
tasks.transcript: It's time the authorities took decisive action to increase affordable housing construction.

options.text: The authorities should start acting firmly to build more affordable homes.
The authorities have already solved the housing crisis.
No action is needed regarding affordable housing.
The housing crisis does not actually exist.

tasks.explanation: 'It's time + past tense' signals that action should have started already. The speaker urges the authorities to begin addressing the housing shortage now.

tasks.audioText: The mother spoke with concern about her teenage son's lifestyle. I'd sooner he focused on his studies than spent every evening playing video games.
tasks.transcript: I'd sooner he focused on his studies than spent every evening playing video games.

options.text: She encourages her son to play more video games.
She would prefer her son to prioritize schoolwork over gaming every night.
Her son is an excellent student who never plays games.
She thinks video games are more important than studying.

tasks.explanation: 'I'd sooner + past tense' expresses preference using the unreal past, similar to 'would rather'. She wants him to study instead of gaming.

tasks.audioText: The journalist investigated corporate lobbying practices. What if the public knew how much influence corporations actually had over legislative decisions?
tasks.transcript: What if the public knew how much influence corporations actually had over legislative decisions?

options.text: The public is fully aware of corporate influence on legislation.
Corporations have no influence over any laws.
The journalist speculates about how people would react if they discovered the true extent of corporate power over laws.
The journalist has no interest in lobbying.

tasks.explanation: 'What if + past tense' uses the unreal past to pose a hypothetical question about a present situation. The public does not currently know the extent of influence.

tasks.audioText: The financial advisor met with a couple nearing retirement. I'd rather you didn't invest your entire pension in a single high-risk fund at this stage.
tasks.transcript: I'd rather you didn't invest your entire pension in a single high-risk fund at this stage.

options.text: The advisor recommends putting all pension savings into one risky investment.
They have already invested all their money in a risky fund.
The advisor prefers that they avoid putting all retirement funds into one high-risk investment right now.
The advisor thinks the couple is too young to retire.

tasks.explanation: 'I'd rather you didn't' uses the unreal past to politely express a negative preference. The advisor counsels against concentrating pension in one risky place.

tasks.audioText: The astronaut recalled his first space mission during an interview. Looking back, I sometimes wish I had taken more photographs of Earth from the observation deck.
tasks.transcript: Looking back, I sometimes wish I had taken more photographs of Earth from the observation deck.

options.text: He took plenty of photographs during his mission.
He regrets not capturing more images of Earth while he was in space.
He never went to space.
He plans to take more photographs on his next mission.

tasks.explanation: 'Wish + past perfect' expresses regret about a past action that cannot be changed. He did not photograph Earth enough and feels sorry about it now.

tasks.audioText: The sustainability officer presented the annual report. Suppose every company adopted carbon-neutral practices — the cumulative effect on global emissions would be transformative.
tasks.transcript: Suppose every company adopted carbon-neutral practices — the cumulative effect on global emissions would be transformative.

options.text: All companies have already adopted carbon-neutral practices.
Carbon-neutral practices would have no impact on emissions.
If all businesses went carbon-neutral, the combined impact on worldwide emissions would be revolutionary.
The officer believes carbon neutrality is impossible.

tasks.explanation: 'Suppose + past tense' introduces a hypothetical scenario using the unreal past. Universal adoption would dramatically change global emission levels.
